ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live Q&A session
Recorded lecture with live Q&A once per week.
This class consisted of recorded lectures with a once a week 30min - 1 hour question session with the instructor.
Lectures were recorded and then once a week there was a live virtual discussion.
The class was a combination of recorded lectures (about 1-2 hours worth per week) and in person Q&A sessions (30 min per week).
There was a combination between pre-recorded lectures and live virtual Q&A sessions.

Recorded lecture
Live Office Hours for questions and discussion
Recorded Lecture with live virtual discussion once a week
There was also a once a week town hall Q&A.
Recorded lecture with live section discussion.
There were two 3-4 part recorded lectures, between 7-20 minutes each, and a live 50 min section once a week.
In addition to recorded lecture, there was one synchronous zoom meeting per week (not mandatory but recommended).
Synchronous session once a week
Live Q&A sessions (30 mins to 60 mins).

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a basic understanding of multiple topics pertaining to globalization and its effects.

I learned a lot from this course. It covers everything that economics touches in the global realm. I learned a lot of economic insights that I ended up using in one of my final papers for another class.

I learned about how globalization affects trade patterns within a country and between countries. This course was very informative and I learned about how various models predict trade patterns as well as various socio-economic factors for trade.
To analyze and discuss how preferences are aggregated, and how these preferences are reflected in governmental decisions and implementation of public policies.
Learned how to read a data table
I developed a knowledge of basic international political economy and game theory.

I learned about modern theories of political economy. I learned about trade politics, international finance, aid and loan disbursement, and global climate change efforts. The course also covered comparative/absolute advantage, game theory (prisoner's dilemma), exchange rate and other elements of macroeconomics. I developed the ability to identify and compare economic and cultural theories on trade policy.

This course instilled the framework of International Political Economy in its students. The class covers a variety of seminal papers/concepts in IPE and then moves to applications of these concepts (climate change, foreign aid, etc)
This class taught me a lot about trade, international finances, cooperation games, and other incentives/strategies that motivate international behaviors and negotiations.
Theoretical underpinnings of various political economy phenomena, understanding of trade-offs of globalization and its distributional consequences.
I learned how to apply many different political science models to the real world through examples and pressing modern issues.

I learned the basics of the IPE approach to understanding global and domestic issues. Additionally, I was introduced to a variety of (very relevant) topics, such as international trade, how trade affects situations "at home", monetary policy, migration, foreign investment, foreign aid, and international cooperation on climate change.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - lectures are organized and correspond to problem sets 
Weaknesses - some weeks had a lot of long readings
Overall, it was great. The recorded lectures were helpful as it gave me flexibility and allowed me to rewatch whenever I needed. There were no real downsides.

The assignments were a bit weird. There seemed to be a focus on preparing us for the "real world," which I find utterly pointless. The questions could have been more geared towards understanding and engaging with the material to think deeper and more critically about it instead of just regurgitating readings and lecture notes.
Also, I don't think there was enough focus on Western imperialism
This course was very interesting. I definitely learned a lot. The concepts are both very interesting and honestly just super useful to know.

The strengths of this course were the slides because they were very useful. A weakness would be that the class goes very fast and so I believe it might be best to cut down on the class topics if it meant exploring each topic a bit more thorough.
Poorly written questions. Often confused on what TAs and Professor wanted.
The strengths were the readings and the lectures, the in person segment could be a little bit weak at times.

The strength of this course lied in the reading materials and Professor Queralt's lecturing style. His lectures had lots of links and other resources for students, which was helpful due to the asynchronous nature of the course. The articles were engaging and informative, though there was a heavy focus on the U.S. and China, and it would have been nice to explore more country's. The assignments were interesting, but more clearly defined expectations would have been helpful.
Prof. Didac is a very clear lecturer and cares a great deal about his student's ability to learn

The course's material was interesting. A strength is Professors Queralt's review of the relevant studies during the lectures. It made it accessible and also the syllabus is very well organized, which very helpful when answering the assignments. A weakness, the class moves really fast, not only the speaking pace but content-wise it might be hard to keep up with especially towards the middle of the course.

Strengths: excellent structure, very clear lecture that left few loose ends with regards to the content covered. Many opportunities for support from instructor and TAs. Weakness: prescriptive grading structure.
I think there should be more assignments with less weight on each one.

Strengths: The lectures were excellent. Professor Queralt explained concepts very clearly. Additionally, the weekly Q&A sessions were helpful in keeping me "on track" with the course. I also enjoyed the discussion board questions since they gave students opportunities to apply what we learned in class to "real world" issues in politics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Pre recorded lectures were very helpful. The Q&A felt like a waste of time sometimes and more like office hours so maybe not make this part of the participation grade.
Same as above. Recorded lectures were great and the Q&A was a good way to ask the professor questions.

I think the virtual q&a sessions were super helpful in allowing for the class to be as interactive as necessary. There could have been more quizzes or weekly check-ins (maybe ungraded like a disscussion) with the TA as a check to see where you are in the class.
The prerecorded lectures were particularly helpful as they allowed me to pause and rewind to fully understand each concept.
They did fine.

I thought that more discussion posts would have been nice. I appreciated the ones we had, but due to the limited synchronous aspects, I didn't really know any of my classmates. I think more student interactions in general would have been nice.
The short answer assignments were a good way to assure you kept up with the content. I think the midterm exam was unnecessary.
the synchronous sessions were very good, but the recorded sessions could be posted earlier to allow more flexibility.

The lectures were organized and easy to follow. Submitting assignments was easy, and Professor Queralt was avaliable to answer students' questions, whether during the Q&A sessions or over email. 

The asynchronous format had its pros and cons. On one hand, it allowed for greater flexibility. On the other hand, it was easy to fall behind on lectures and/or readings (though obviously this is my fault and not the instructors'). For this reason, I thought the Q&A sessions were very helpful. Even though I did not always ask questions during the sessions, the sessions kept me "grounded" throughout the course and motivated me to pace myself appropriately.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this class if you are interested in global politics and want to touch on many topics. The problem sets seem hard at first but when you look through the notes they become relatively easy. The workload is manageable and the knowledge you gain is very useful.
Of course, this class is a class that every Yale student should take. It gives you important insights into how the world operates and it teaches you a range of important information.
Yes. This class was very informative and good to understand how global trade patterns work.
I would recommend it if this is something you are interested in.
Absolutely. The concepts I learned here are concepts that I still think about and are really useful. The professor is great and very clear in his lectures.
Yes, it is a very solid class.
Yes. Whether you want to work in the public or private sphere, you'll learn about different topics than involve decision-making in both areas.
Hard to figure out what Professor / TAs wanted. Questions poorly worded. Not much work. Not hard to do well. Just rather confusing.
If youre interested in IPE, Prof. Queralt is great and the class is interesting.

Yes. The content was really interesting. I learned a lot about trade politics that I think will be very applicable in the future. While it is definitely not an economics course, it gives a good overview on some economic concepts too, such as exchange rates, the production possibility frontier, and the prisoner's dilemma. Also, Professor Queralt is really nice and enthusiastic about the subject.
Yes, it is an introductory course but I had very limited previous knowledge so it was perfect for me.
Yes, great lectures, interesting content.
Yes, I would, it was fascinating and the professor was great.

Yes. This course covers some very important topics in today's world, and more importantly, it teaches the tools and methods by which one may better understand these issues in an informed and scientific manner. Additionally, Professor Queralt explains concepts clearly and his lectures are engaging.
